name: Disability
description: The Disability segment (DB1) contains information about a patient's disabilities. This segment is important for ADT (Admit, Discharge, Transfer) workflows and care planning, providing essential information about functional limitations, accommodations needed, and accessibility requirements. The DB1 segment helps healthcare organizations ensure appropriate care delivery, facility planning, and compliance with disability-related regulations such as the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

cardinality.note: Multiple DB1 segments can be used for different disabilities

DB1.1.name: Set ID - DB1
DB1.1.description: This field contains the sequence number for the DB1 segment when multiple disability segments are present.
DB1.1.generationHint: Sequential numbering: 1, 2, 3, etc. for multiple disabilities

DB1.2.name: Disabled Person Code
DB1.2.description: This field indicates whether the patient is classified as a disabled person according to legal or institutional definitions.
DB1.2.generationHint: Y for patients with documented disabilities, N for confirmed non-disabled

DB1.3.name: Disabled Person Identifier
DB1.3.description: This field contains a unique identifier for the disabled person, which may be assigned by a government agency or healthcare organization.
DB1.3.generationHint: Government disability ID number or organizational disability identifier

DB1.4.name: Disability Indicator
DB1.4.description: This field indicates the presence and nature of a disability. This is a more specific indicator than the general disabled person code.
DB1.4.generationHint: Y for documented functional limitations or impairments

DB1.5.name: Disability Start Date
DB1.5.description: This field contains the date when the disability was first recognized or diagnosed.
DB1.5.generationHint: Date of disability onset, injury, or diagnosis

DB1.6.name: Disability End Date
DB1.6.description: This field contains the date when the disability ended or is expected to end, if applicable.
DB1.6.generationHint: Usually empty for permanent disabilities, populated for temporary impairments

DB1.7.name: Disability Return to Work Date
DB1.7.description: This field contains the date when the person is expected to return to work following a disability.
DB1.7.generationHint: Projected return-to-work date for work-related injuries or temporary disabilities

DB1.8.name: Disability Unable to Work Date
DB1.8.description: This field contains the date when the person became unable to work due to the disability.
DB1.8.generationHint: Date when work disability began, important for workers' compensation cases

epic.notes: Epic integrates disability information with care planning and facility management

cerner.notes: Cerner emphasizes compliance and accommodation management for disabled patients

allscripts.notes: Allscripts provides essential disability tracking for care delivery modifications

nextgen.notes: NextGen focuses on work-related disability management and return-to-work coordination

notes: DB1 segment helps ensure appropriate accommodations and care for disabled patients
Set ID (DB1.1) is the only required field, making this a flexible segment
Disability dates help track temporary vs. permanent disabilities
Work-related date fields are important for workers' compensation and occupational health
Multiple DB1 segments can document different types or aspects of disabilities
Information supports ADA compliance and accessibility planning

dataConsistency.disabilityIndicatorAlignment: Disabled Person Code (DB1.2) and Disability Indicator (DB1.4) should be consistent
dataConsistency.dateLogic: Start date should precede end date and return-to-work date
dataConsistency.workStatusConsistency: Work-related dates should align with disability type and duration
dataConsistency.identifierValidation: Disability identifiers should follow issuing authority format

businessRules.accommodationTracking: Disabilities requiring accommodations should trigger care planning workflows
businessRules.complianceRequirements: Disability information must comply with ADA and HIPAA regulations
businessRules.careCoordination: Disability status should be communicated to relevant care team members
businessRules.temporaryDisabilities: Temporary disabilities should have appropriate follow-up scheduling
businessRules.workRelatedInjuries: Work-related disabilities require coordination with occupational health services
